for the short story cassandra we asked cherry if she'd been reading science fiction since childhood yes i i started reading science fiction i suppose this is about the earliest form of literature that i read i never made a mental distinction between science fiction fantasy uh anything of that nature because uh my parents brought it to me to read and uh i just simply regarded it as the most interesting the reading material that i had accessible so naturally when i began turning to writing that's what i wrote she went on to tell us why she decided to start writing science fiction actually they took my television program off the air um our television at that time i was 10 television hadn't been around in private homes very long i had just time enough to get thoroughly addicted to uh television science fiction and then it ran its course and it was gone from the air so i in a fit of mourning and went into uh uh the bedroom picked up a tablet and pencil and started writing my own novels cherry is a talented writer with a flair for style and structure she might have been successful in any form of writing she chose to pursue she tells us why she didn't write other kinds of books well i didn't write the other things because i didn't like them in general um i find that uh uh i suppose the only thing outside of science fiction that i've ever tried my hand at writing has been mysteries um and i don't care for the modern fashion of those and i've always viewed them as a great deal more fun to read than they are to write um mostly because you have to be extremely controlled um and i suspect that mystery writers have to know who who did it um and i'd rather not know the end of my book um the other thing that i've tried my hand at is historical fiction and i find again that's a straight jacket because you're rather well held with what happened whether or not it makes artistic sense so um just for the sheer pleasure of writing i prefer science fiction donald walheim the owner and editor of da books discovered cherry when she sent him the manuscript for gate of ivril she explains why she picked walheim i grew fascinated with um with walheim as an editor because i had gone through my library finally after seven years of trying to sell things and i thought well there there must be a system to this you see i had no professional help at all and um i began searching my library to see what editor had published the majority of uh works and writers that i liked figuring that we might have something in common as far as taste goes uh um so i began researching don walheim to see um um um what his preferences were uh where we differed and where we were similar and uh so i began to conclude more and more that uh we were fairly well synthetico when it came to uh to taste uh not quite the same all the way down the line but uh generally there's a broad area of overlap uh so i found him very easy to work with we'll have more with cj cherry next Coming up next is the Science Fiction Radio Show, so stay with us. This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy. And here are your hosts. This is Daryl Lane. And David Cruz. C.J. Cherry's 1982 novel, The Pride of Channer, is a fascinating depiction of alien cultures. Essentially, there's only one human in the entire book, a wretched man named Tully, who's been picked up after an accident aboard his spaceship. The aliens who end up with him are called the Honey. We are with the Honey for the length of the novel, seeing everything from their alien perspective. The Honey look and act like lions. We asked Cherry if this was deliberate. Yes, absolutely. This is one case where I've taken the species of lions and, in a very simple way, devised a culture of an advanced species, which very closely parallels the biology and, if you will, social patterns of a lion pride. The title of the book, of course, is a three-way pun. As an alert reader soon figures out, there is a three-way pun on the title of Pride of Channer. Pride of lions, the pride characteristic of the Honey species, and the name of the Honey spaceship, which is called the Pride of Channer. Tully, the human who falls into Honey hands and gets mixed up in an interstellar war, is a pitiful creature who both fears and needs the honey. Cherry explains why he instinctively fears the lion-like species. Have you ever seen a baboon react to a leopard? It's raw terror. A primate's nervous system is not really set up to be setting in the center of a pride of lions. It's really one of the most unkind things, I believe, that you could do to a human being, as far as social patterns would be, to drop them right into the middle of a feline culture. Sure, because the moves are all wrong. Well, for instance, Tully, being a primate, smiles. And, of course, this is exactly the wrong thing to do. You know what a lion does when it smiles. It's not a friendly gesture. Every gesture he makes is wrong. At least as far as he's concerned. In his own way, though, Cherry says, Tully acts with courage. He is, however, a very heroic human being, if you just simply analyze what he has done. He has managed to survive a very horrendous situation. He has managed to collect himself with some dignity out of a situation which would have broken drastically. Any average individual would have definitely come out of it damaged. He's been forced to take horrendous decisions, and he's been dumped into a situation where even his personal value is of some question. And yet he manages to stand up on his hind feet and confront the honey captain with a here I am, come and see if you can do something about it kind of attitude, which is, of course, what wins the captain's respect in the beginning. He calms down a little bit, as you will see, when he begins trying to deal with them, doing what any sensible person would do when confronted with a situation where you suspect that the beings around you are at least essentially friendly, and there's no need provoking something that would be a total misunderstanding. So he does remain a little bit quiet, but he's quiet partially because he's smart and is trying to absorb more data than he gives out. The Pride of Channer is a typical C.J. Cherry narrative, well plotted with finely drawn alien cultures and full of exciting and realistic space battles. And that's what we've come to expect from Cherry. She doesn't seem to know how to write a bad book. More with C.J. Cherry on our next show. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show, a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association, produced in conjunction with Odessa College in Odessa, Texas. Coming up next is the Science Fiction Radio Show, so stay with us. This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy. And here are your hosts. This is David Cruz. And Daryl Lane. One of the finest science fiction trilogies in recent years is C.J. Cherry's Faded Sun series. It was published in the late 1970s under the titles Kesrith, Shongir, and Kutath. There are few books in science fiction that present an alien culture with the sensitivity and depth that Cherry has given to one of the alien races in the trilogy, the Mree. The Mree are nomadic tribesmen of the desert. They are great warriors, and space-faring races employ them as mercenaries. Cherry says she didn't pattern the Mree on any modern nomadic cultures, but she used her knowledge of ancient history. When I did the Faded Sun novels, which are basically a desert culture, I did not pattern it off any modern desert culture about which I know, frankly, nothing. I patterned it strictly by taking what I know about desert survival and earlier nomadic cultures here on Earth, contrived a biology that would work under the extreme conditions that I postulated, and then drew elements from here and there. It's very strange that I now get letters from people that say that it very closely resembles a modern terrestrial nomadic culture. But this is strictly a surprise to me. I suppose it just says that I knew something about the very ancient one. We asked Cherry what she most admired about the Mree. I think that, for one thing, about the Mree, I think I admire their steadfastness, their ability to face time itself with tranquility, in the sense that they can take the long view, which is a thing that is absolutely necessary, in my mind, for civilized survival. In my mind, I don't say just survival, but civilized survival. It's their ability to look down the centuries and see consequences. The Mree sense of time is a very strange thing. A Mree always lives now, and that now is a composite of the past, current events, and the future simultaneously. They do not view time as the modern American does, which is more or less a set of beads on the string that we can snip off any tail of the string that seems inconvenient to us. The Mree concept of the universe is holistic. The Mree have almost been wiped out, because they've been used as pawns in an interstellar war between humans and another alien culture, the Regal. Duncan, a human who's been partly responsible for the Mree's seemingly certain demise, is conscience-stricken at the possible end of such a beautiful and ancient culture. His solution is to attempt to become a Mree, although it may kill him and will certainly destroy his humanity. His final sacrifice, in a sort of a redemptive sense, is that he finally agrees that he will no longer attempt to be human, that he begins to try to be something else. Even in that, there is a considerable hazard, because if the transition is not complete, he may end up by contaminating the culture, which to the Mree and their way of life is a very, very serious thing. But it is a voluntary and conscious decision that effectively it is personal suicide. And he takes it because he feels responsible for what has happened. Duncan's attempt to become a Mree is one of the most sensitive treatments of human-alien contact in science fiction. We'll have more with C.J. Cherry on our next program. Where is the ENVIRCARE your file In the dirt or in the winter Coming up next is the Science Fiction Radio Show, so stay with us. This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy. And here are your hosts. This is Daryl Lane and David Cruz. Hunter of Worlds, a 1977 novel by C.J. Cherry, is a different sort of science fiction book, a difficult one that surprised a few of its readers. Cherry has created a language for one of the alien cultures in the novel, and the narrative is sprinkled with strange words that slow a reader down. Cherry admits that Hunter of Worlds is different from other works. Hunter of Worlds is constructed for different reasons. Usually when I use alien languages in a book, it is not for local color, it's just that when you run across anybody's civilization, which is vastly different than your own, you're going to come across three or four words which cannot be translated, no matter how you would like to. It's just that not all languages have words for concepts. Well, you know, like in English, you can think of several things that you can say that you can't say in French and vice versa, which is why language borrows words from other languages. When I did Hunter of Worlds, I was doing something totally different, and it is an experimental novel, and it is not a novel that I recommend to someone who is not used to science fiction or not used to language, one or the other. Basically on that one, the very premise of the book is linguistics, treating the science of linguistics, as you will, as seriously as you treat physics in a science fiction novel. I deliberately set out to make a language which is not based on any earthly model. I even changed the rules of grammar to something that, as far as I know, is not directly based on any grammatical system on the face of the earth. The thing is explained in an appendix in the back for people who wish to do this kind of thing. Cherry has some advice for those who read the novel. There are several ways to read the book. The first one, the recommended one, is as the viewpoint character sees it. Frankly, the viewpoint character is confused as all get out most of the time. He doesn't understand. So you can equally well appreciate the book simply by realizing that from his viewpoint, a lot of these people are speaking things at him which he in no wise comprehends. The trouble with the book is that, of course, at several points he's vastly mistaken about what he thinks he understands. So the book does have some pitfalls in it for somebody who is accustomed to believing everything that the hero in a novel believes must ergo be the truth because he is very, very frequently mistaken or very, very frequently picks up a concept which is not the whole concept and gradually begins to arrive at an understanding of what's going on toward the end of the book. But I must warn everyone that even at the end he is somewhat mistaken. Cherry says she has a special affection for the novel. Cherry says she has a special affection for the novel. And that one is sort of a... one of the very, very strange books that I can reread and find something I didn't know was there. It's just kind of an odd feeling. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show, a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association, produced in conjunction with Odessa College in Odessa, Texas. Coming up next is the Science Fiction Radio Show, so stay with us.
This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy.
And here are your hosts.
This is Daryl Lane.
And David Cruz.
C.J. Cherry's 1982 novel, The Pride of Channer, is a fascinating depiction of alien cultures.
Essentially, there's only one human in the entire book, a wretched man named Tully, who's been picked up after an accident aboard his spaceship.
The aliens who end up with him are called the Honey.
We are with the Honey for the length of the novel, seeing everything from their alien perspective.
The Honey look and act like lions. We asked Cherry if this was deliberate.
Yes, absolutely.

This is one case where I've taken the species of lions and, in a very simple way, devised a culture of an advanced species, which very closely parallels the biology and, if you will, social patterns of a lion pride.
The title of the book, of course, is a three-way pun.
As an alert reader soon figures out, there is a three-way pun on the title of Pride of Channer.
Pride of lions, the pride characteristic of the Honey species, and the name of the Honey spaceship, which is called the Pride of Channer.
Tully, the human who falls into Honey hands and gets mixed up in an interstellar war, is a pitiful creature who both fears and needs the honey.
Cherry explains why he instinctively fears the lion-like species.
Have you ever seen a baboon react to a leopard?
It's raw terror.
A primate's nervous system is not really set up to be setting in the center of a pride of lions.
It's really one of the most unkind things, I believe, that you could do to a human being, as far as social patterns would be, to drop them right into the middle of a feline culture.
Sure, because the moves are all wrong.
Well, for instance, Tully, being a primate, smiles.
And, of course, this is exactly the wrong thing to do.
You know what a lion does when it smiles.
It's not a friendly gesture.
Every gesture he makes is wrong.
At least as far as he's concerned.
In his own way, though, Cherry says, Tully acts with courage.
He is, however, a very heroic human being, if you just simply analyze what he has done.
He has managed to survive a very horrendous situation.
He has managed to collect himself with some dignity out of a situation which would have broken drastically.
Any average individual would have definitely come out of it damaged.
He's been forced to take horrendous decisions, and he's been dumped into a situation where even his personal value is of some question.
And yet he manages to stand up on his hind feet and confront the honey captain with a here I am, come and see if you can do something about it kind of attitude,
which is, of course, what wins the captain's respect in the beginning.

He calms down a little bit, as you will see, when he begins trying to deal with them, doing what any sensible person would do when confronted with a situation where you suspect that the beings around you are at least essentially friendly,
and there's no need provoking something that would be a total misunderstanding.
So he does remain a little bit quiet, but he's quiet partially because he's smart and is trying to absorb more data than he gives out.
The Pride of Channer is a typical C.J. Cherry narrative, well plotted with finely drawn alien cultures and full of exciting and realistic space battles.
And that's what we've come to expect from Cherry. She doesn't seem to know how to write a bad book.
More with C.J. Cherry on our next show.

Coming up next is the Science Fiction Radio Show, so stay with us.
This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy.
And here are your hosts.
This is David Cruz.
And Daryl Lane.
One of the finest science fiction trilogies in recent years is C.J. Cherry's Faded Sun series.
It was published in the late 1970s under the titles Kesrith, Shongir, and Kutath.
There are few books in science fiction that present an alien culture with the sensitivity and depth that Cherry has given to one of the alien races in the trilogy, the Mree.
The Mree are nomadic tribesmen of the desert.
They are great warriors, and space-faring races employ them as mercenaries.
Cherry says she didn't pattern the Mree on any modern nomadic cultures, but she used her knowledge of ancient history.
When I did the Faded Sun novels, which are basically a desert culture, I did not pattern it off any modern desert culture about which I know, frankly, nothing.
I patterned it strictly by taking what I know about desert survival and earlier nomadic cultures here on Earth,
contrived a biology that would work under the extreme conditions that I postulated,
and then drew elements from here and there.
It's very strange that I now get letters from people that say that it very closely resembles a modern terrestrial nomadic culture.
But this is strictly a surprise to me.
I suppose it just says that I knew something about the very ancient one.
We asked Cherry what she most admired about the Mree.
I think that, for one thing, about the Mree, I think I admire their steadfastness,
their ability to face time itself with tranquility,
in the sense that they can take the long view,
which is a thing that is absolutely necessary, in my mind, for civilized survival.
In my mind, I don't say just survival, but civilized survival.
It's their ability to look down the centuries and see consequences.
The Mree sense of time is a very strange thing.
A Mree always lives now, and that now is a composite of the past,
current events, and the future simultaneously.
They do not view time as the modern American does,
which is more or less a set of beads on the string
that we can snip off any tail of the string that seems inconvenient to us.
The Mree concept of the universe is holistic.
The Mree have almost been wiped out,
because they've been used as pawns in an interstellar war
between humans and another alien culture, the Regal.
Duncan, a human who's been partly responsible
for the Mree's seemingly certain demise,
is conscience-stricken at the possible end
of such a beautiful and ancient culture.
His solution is to attempt to become a Mree,
although it may kill him and will certainly destroy his humanity.
His final sacrifice, in a sort of a redemptive sense,
is that he finally agrees that he will no longer attempt to be human,
that he begins to try to be something else.
Even in that, there is a considerable hazard,
because if the transition is not complete,
he may end up by contaminating the culture,
which to the Mree and their way of life is a very, very serious thing.
But it is a voluntary and conscious decision
that effectively it is personal suicide.
And he takes it because he feels responsible for what has happened.
Duncan's attempt to become a Mree
is one of the most sensitive treatments

Coming up next is the Science Fiction Radio Show, so stay with us.
This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy.
And here are your hosts.
This is Daryl Lane and David Cruz.
Hunter of Worlds, a 1977 novel by C.J. Cherry, is a different sort of science fiction book,
a difficult one that surprised a few of its readers.
Cherry has created a language for one of the alien cultures in the novel,
and the narrative is sprinkled with strange words that slow a reader down.
Cherry admits that Hunter of Worlds is different from other works.
Hunter of Worlds is constructed for different reasons.
Usually when I use alien languages in a book, it is not for local color,
it's just that when you run across anybody's civilization,
which is vastly different than your own,
you're going to come across three or four words which cannot be translated,
no matter how you would like to.
It's just that not all languages have words for concepts.
Well, you know, like in English, you can think of several things that you can say that you can't say in French and vice versa,
which is why language borrows words from other languages.
When I did Hunter of Worlds, I was doing something totally different,
and it is an experimental novel, and it is not a novel that I recommend to someone who is not used to science fiction
or not used to language, one or the other.
Basically on that one, the very premise of the book is linguistics,
treating the science of linguistics, as you will, as seriously as you treat physics in a science fiction novel.
I deliberately set out to make a language which is not based on any earthly model.
I even changed the rules of grammar to something that, as far as I know,
is not directly based on any grammatical system on the face of the earth.
The thing is explained in an appendix in the back for people who wish to do this kind of thing.
Cherry has some advice for those who read the novel.
There are several ways to read the book.
The first one, the recommended one, is as the viewpoint character sees it.
Frankly, the viewpoint character is confused as all get out most of the time.
He doesn't understand.
So you can equally well appreciate the book simply by realizing that from his viewpoint,
a lot of these people are speaking things at him which he in no wise comprehends.
The trouble with the book is that, of course, at several points he's vastly mistaken about what he thinks he understands.
So the book does have some pitfalls in it for somebody who is accustomed to believing everything
that the hero in a novel believes must ergo be the truth because he is very, very frequently mistaken
or very, very frequently picks up a concept which is not the whole concept
and gradually begins to arrive at an understanding of what's going on toward the end of the book.
But I must warn everyone that even at the end he is somewhat mistaken.
Cherry says she has a special affection for the novel.
Cherry says she has a special affection for the novel.
And that one is sort of a...
one of the very, very strange books that I can reread and find something I didn't know was there.
It's just kind of an odd feeling.
